title: Simple Subtraction on the Soroban: The Opposite of Addition
description: If addition means moving beads toward the beam, subtraction is the reverse. Here's how to introduce basic subtraction.

content.intro: Subtraction on the soroban is simply the reverse of addition. Instead of moving beads toward the beam, you move them away. Let's start simple.

sections.text: To SUBTRACT: Move beads AWAY from the beam. Lower beads go DOWN (using index finger). Upper bead goes UP (using index finger).

items: **Step 1:** Set 5 (push upper bead down to beam)
**Step 2:** Subtract 2... but no lower beads to remove!
**Step 3:** Exchange: Push upper bead UP, push 3 lower beads UP

sections.text: Wait, that seems complicated. Let's try an easier one first.
When you can't directly subtract (like 5 - 2), you use the upper bead:
To subtract from 5 when you only have the upper bead: subtract 5, add the complement. 5-2 → remove 5, add 3. Kids learn this pattern naturally.

faq.question: Why is subtraction harder than addition?
faq.answer: It requires a mental "flip" – removing instead of adding. Also, complements come up more often. Practice makes it automatic.

faq.question: Should my child master addition before subtraction?
faq.answer: Not necessarily. Many curriculums teach them together since they're inverse operations. But if subtraction causes frustration, focus on addition first.

faq.question: What about bigger numbers?
faq.answer: Same principles, just more columns. 15 - 3 uses the same technique as 5 - 3, you're just working in the tens column first.
